references.authors: SULKIN SE, GREVE MJ.

caseDefinition.investigationDefinition: Cases with Human Rabies attributed to a Bat RABV

infectionSourceAdditionalDescription: "Three weeks prior to admission and sixteen days prior to theonset of her illness, the patient had stopped to investigate what was apparently a dead bat o the roadside. The animal,however was not dead, and on investigating at close range the patient was bitten on the left forearm."

references.title: A fatal case of rabies in a woman bitten by an insectivorous bat
references.authors: Humphrey, G. L., Kemp, G. E., Wood, E. G.
IRONS JV, EADS RB, GRIMES JE, CONKLIN A

caseDefinition.investigationDefinition: Cases with Human Rabies attributed to a Bat RABV

infectionSourceAdditionalDescription: "He had been engaged in research on bat rabies in Texas, capturing, handling, and banding insectivorous bats in caves from April through November 1955. Isolation of rabies virus had been made from bats taken from the caves where he had worked. He had also inoculated bats with rabies virus several months before his death. How and when he was infected even he did not know. He is known to have worked extensively, however in Frio CAve, Uvalde County, a cave which figures prominetnly in the histor of the fourth case." [1] ""In the field M. Menzies handled a tremendous number of bats while wearing rubber gloves. In April, May and June, 1966, he and several associates banded some 10,000 in connection with migration studies. On Nov 15, 1955 he made a trip to Frio Cave in Uvalde County during the course of which several hundred bats were examined in a search for banded specimens. On October 20, 1955, he made a trip to Bracken Cave in Comal County to look for banded bats and Wilson Cave in Kerr Count was visited October 13, 1955 for the same purposes. In retropsect, it has een postulated that Mr. Menzies acuquired his inection through the contamination of his gloves and the accidental rubbing of his neck at the site of a chronic skin eruption."[2]

In attempting to place it in a tree where her two dogs would not further molest it, she was bitte on the middle figer of the left hand."

references.authors: Centers for Disease Control

caseDefinition.investigationDefinition: Cases with Human Rabies attributed to a Bat RABV

infectionSourceAdditionalDescription: "While hospitalized, the patient denied any history of animal bites, and an interview with the patient's husband on November 15 did not establish a history of contact with bats or other animals. The couple lived in an old house in a rural area and reported frequently hearing noises in the chimney that sounded like birds. However, investigation of the residence by the local health department did not detect evidence of bats in the house or chimney."

labTestsAndResults.textualName: Serum, saliva, and nuchal skin biopsy specimens

references.title: Human Rabies -- Kentucky and Montana, 1996
references.authors: Centers for Disease Control

caseDefinition.investigationDefinition: Cases with Human Rabies attributed to a Bat RABV

infectionSourceAdditionalDescription: "The patient and his family lived in a rural area and reported occasionally seeing bats outside their home but denied having had physical contact with bats. In addition, the patient was employed as a custodian for a wood and paper mill and denied contact with bats at his workplace. Although coworkers reported that bats were sometimes observed near the mill premises, the Missoula City-County Health Department inspected the site after the patient's death and found no evidence of bats."

labTestsAndResults.result: Negri bodes throughout the brain tissue with highest density in the cerebellum and hippocampus.

references.title: Human Rabies -- Montana and Washington, 1997
references.authors: Centers for Disease Control

caseDefinition.investigationDefinition: Cases with Human Rabies attributed to a Bat RABV

infectionSourceAdditionalDescription: "His family could not recall any history of contact with ill animals during these activities but reported that he baited traps with decayed animals he had collected from roadsides, often removing meat from the carcasses without wearing gloves. They also recalled that a bat had entered their home through the bedroom window in late summer 1996. On subsequent days, the bat was observed to be roosting during the daytime and flying around the house at dusk, and the patient eventually forced the bat out of the house with a broom. The patient's wife denied known contact with the bat and did not recall her husband having reported direct contact with the animal at any time. The bat had been driven from the house approximately 4 months before the onset of the patient's illness."

infectionSourceAdditionalDescription: "The woman contracted the disease,... from a bat that flew into the family home in the middle of the night on Aug. 21 and brushed against her face and leg, " " Musgrave said." "A family member carefully checked her for signs of a bite but found none"
